text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Andrew Cone.

I'm graduating in
the class of 2017
from Harvard Business School.
And I am the Class Day speaker.

I studied art history
as an undergrad.

I'm a younger
brother, and I really

believe that birth
order has a lot
to do with how people turn out.

My brother was
always very academic,

and so I became kind
of the zany one.

I really love diagnosing
social dynamics,

sort of like an anthropological
take on advertising.

My favorite class here by
far was brand strategy,

which really dives
into how to explore

consumer behavior
and really just

people's behavior, in the
current state of economics,
social dynamics, technology.

So at HBS there's a
huge focus on numbers.

And as allergic as I am to Excel
and financial spreadsheets,

you know I've come to
see how storytelling

can be super powerful, coming
from a quantitative point
of view.

But in my heart, I love
words and storytelling

and how you can weave
emotions in and out

of personal and
professional stories.

And I think that can be
done motivating employees.

I think it can be done
motivating consumers.

And I think can be done
motivating ourselves.

Not just as business people
but as people, in 2017, given

the extraordinary privileges
we've had in our education,

I would hope that we
use those same tools

and that same attitude
to participate
in the world around us.

I don't mean around, you
know, a boardroom table.

I really mean around a dining
room table, for instance.

Or when you're getting
coffee with friends.

Or when you're in a public
place and you see something.

Or when you have a
voice in your head

that says should
I be saying this?
Should I reach out?
Should I make my voice heard?

I guess my speech is an
encouragement to do so.

Individuals have real power
in the words they use.

I think we all want more
out of each other than just

a list of things that we've
done or people we've met
or companies we've worked for.
